title: Office Makeover Phase One: Wallpaper and Paint
description: Moody library/office makeover with grasscloth wallpaper. I've been hard at work transforming my home office with wallpaper and painted bookcases!Â  I know, I know...I say this a lot. But this space is turning into one of my all time favorite makeovers. I don't think I could love this room more!Â  I shared the design plan for this office makeover a few weeks ago. This project is really entails just finishing up this room more than redoing anything.Â  I've already built the wall of green bookcases and created a huge upholstered pin board on the opposite wall: The room looked great, but I wanted to add some warm finishing details and change a couple of things up. This post may containÂ affiliate links for yourÂ convenience. I may earn a small commission whenÂ you make a purchase through links.Â  See myÂ policies and disclosure pageÂ for more information.Â Â Â Â  After a few tries with different wallpaper designs, I landed on this neutral grasscloth peel and stick wallpaper for the walls:Â  It worked perfectly with the built ins and was much calmer and easier to work with than the other designs I looked at. I'm so glad I found it! Years ago I shared a tutorial on installing peel and stick wallpaper. I find it kind of satisfying to hang. It has plenty of stick, so you can readjust over and over if needed.Â  You will need clean walls and it is recommended to wait four weeks after painting to apply removable wallpaper.Â  During the install, I had to work around some art. I had a symmetrical set of ten Audubon prints on the long wall in my office, as you can see in this before pic:Â Read the full postThis content is property of Thrifty Decor Chick LLC. If you are reading this on any other site other than www.thriftydecorchick.com or one of the blog's social media platforms, please contact TDC immediately (thriftydecorchick at gmail dot com). Any other use of this content is strictly forbidden.
author: Thrifty Decor Chick
excerpt: Moody library/office makeover with grasscloth wallpaper. I've been hard at work transforming my home office with wallpaper and p...
text: Moody library/office makeover with grasscloth wallpaper. I've been hard at work transforming my home office with wallpaper and painted bookcases!Â  I know, I know...I say this a lot. But this space is turning into one of my all time favorite makeovers. I don't think I could love this room more!Â  I shared the design plan for this office makeover a few weeks ago. This project is really entails just finishing up this room more than redoing anything.Â  The room looked great, but I wanted to add some warm finishing details and change a couple of things up. This post may containÂ affiliate links for yourÂ convenience. I may earn a small commission whenÂ you make a purchase through links.Â  It worked perfectly with the built ins and was much calmer and easier to work with than the other designs I looked at. I'm so glad I found it! You will need clean walls and it is recommended to wait four weeks after painting to apply removable wallpaper.Â  During the install, I had to work around some art. I had a symmetrical set of ten Audubon prints on the long wall in my office, as you can see in this before pic:Â  I've had those forever and still love them! They used to hang in our old living room:Â  So anyway, after hanging those ten frames perfectly spaced out years ago, I did not want to have to do that again.Â  Instead, I kept the nails in the wall as I wallpapered, and then when I got to that spot, I pressed down to feel where the nail was and marked it:Â  I pulled up the peel and stick wallpaper up to remove the nails, then applied it back to the wall normally.Â  When each piece of wallpaper was fully stuck to the wall, I found my marks and reinserted the nails in each spot:Â  This helped a TON! I saved so much time with this method.Â  I spent a couple hours a day working around the top two thirds of the walls hanging the wallpaper. It took a few days, and I was SO thrilled with the outcome!: When I hung this artwork shortly after we moved in, I had no idea I'd be using green in the room. Turns out the Vintage Vogue paint color works perfectly with the leaves in the art. After the wallpaper was up, I started at least some of the trim work that will go around the bottom third of the walls.Â  Because I'll be installing wainscoting, I needed to remove the existing baseboards:Â  I think a large pry bar and a scrap piece of wood works just as well. If you have that, don't waste your money on this tool!Â  I replaced the base with a simpler 1x6 inch wood board that has a flat top, so my trim work can butt directly up to it:Â  While I was at it, I installed that chair rail (1x4 inches) as well. I painted the trim and the space between with the same green paint as the bookcases.Â  I'll be adding some detailed trim between the chair and baseboards soon!Â  The only major item I want to change out in this room is the rug. I tried out a bigger rug I found online and when I laid it out one evening, I really liked it in the room.Â  But there were a couple issues. Even after steaming, it just would not lay flat:Â  The rug comes folded and the creases would not budge. I taped down the edges with rug tape and it still didn't help to flatten it out. I was super concerned this would be a tripping hazard. (I'm not getting any younger!!) ðŸ˜Š Crazy thing was, the rug is so lightweight I couldn't even vacuum it. It would get stuck in the vacuum no matter what setting I had it on.Â  Also, when I walked in the room first thing the next day, I hated the colors. It felt super heavy and way too dark. The description says it's supposed to be green and brown, but I only saw brown and black. So I have a new one on the way that I know I'll like way better. I will say this rug is SO soft! It's a thinner, washable rug and the texture is SO cozy.Â  The next project I completed was changing out the backs of the bookcases. Previously I hung a cherry blossom wallpaper on that wall, and needed to remove it before painting.Â  I used a new, sharp razor blade to lightly score the wallpaper around all the edges:Â  The wallpaper came off almost perfectly! I only had a couple of small spots that pulled away some of the drywall. After the walls were bare, I gave the backs of each shelf three coats of the green paint on the rest of the built ins (Vintage Vogue by Benjamin Moore):Â  Then it was time to start (re)decorating the shelves! The previous wallpaper on the backs was neutral, but still too busy to add a lotÂ to each shelf.Â  Now that the bookcase is all one color, I could fill them a little more. Almost all of the decor is what I had on hand, but I'll link the few newer items below.Â  I find decorating shelves to be the hardest, but I've never been happier with a decorated bookcase or built in before! I had so much fun reworking the decor. The shelves are filled with items and memories I truly love and function perfectly for me.Â  Some of the decor stayed the same, I just moved it around or added to it. I've had those brass elephant bookends forever, and added them to the row of books:Â  The dark vase is from Hobby Lobby and I think I may have gotten the hydrangea stems from there as well, but I've had them for a while. The shelf in the middle pretty much stayed the same, but I gave the artwork frame a quick coat of paint. I'll share all of the little DIYs I've done in this room soon! I've never displayed my college diploma! It's been nearly 30 yearsÂ ðŸ˜³ since I graduated, but I thought why not?Â  This row of shelves is my favorite. :) The only new pieces are the art at the top from Hobby Lobby and the CUTE little brass lamp:Â  I'm adding this to my round up of great countertop lamps! It's just beautiful -- the size is perfect and the scalloped linen shade is a great little detail. It's my favorite decor find in a long time! I also adore that little bitty brass vase on the wall. I found that at an antique store years ago and this is the perfect spot for it.Â  I'll be back soon with more updates in this space! So far I'm thrilled with the progress. I'm focused on making this room really reflect me this time around. I'm sure that's why I love it so much.Â  If I forgot anything or if you have questions about a project I described here, please let me know. Save this post for later by using this image:
html:
Moody library/office makeover with grasscloth wallpaper.

I've been hard at work transforming my home office with wallpaper and painted bookcases!Â 

I know, I know...I say this a lot. But this space is turning into one of my all time favorite makeovers. I don't think I could love this room more!Â 

I shared the design plan for this office makeover a few weeks ago. This project is really entails just finishing up this room more than redoing anything.Â 

The room looked great, but I wanted to add some warm finishing details and change a couple of things up.

This post may containÂ affiliate links for yourÂ convenience.

I may earn a small commission whenÂ you make a purchase through links.Â 

It worked perfectly with the built ins and was much calmer and easier to work with than the other designs I looked at. I'm so glad I found it!

You will need clean walls and it is recommended to wait four weeks after painting to apply removable wallpaper.Â 

During the install, I had to work around some art. I had a symmetrical set of ten Audubon prints on the long wall in my office, as you can see in this before pic:Â 

I've had those forever and still love them! They used to hang in our old living room:Â 

So anyway, after hanging those ten frames perfectly spaced out years ago, I did not want to have to do that again.Â 

Instead, I kept the nails in the wall as I wallpapered, and then when I got to that spot, I pressed down to feel where the nail was and marked it:Â 

I pulled up the peel and stick wallpaper up to remove the nails, then applied it back to the wall normally.Â 

When each piece of wallpaper was fully stuck to the wall, I found my marks and reinserted the nails in each spot:Â 

This helped a TON! I saved so much time with this method.Â 

I spent a couple hours a day working around the top two thirds of the walls hanging the wallpaper. It took a few days, and I was SO thrilled with the outcome!:

When I hung this artwork shortly after we moved in, I had no idea I'd be using green in the room. Turns out the Vintage Vogue paint color works perfectly with the leaves in the art.

After the wallpaper was up, I started at least some of the trim work that will go around the bottom third of the walls.Â 

Because I'll be installing wainscoting, I needed to remove the existing baseboards:Â 

I think a large pry bar and a scrap piece of wood works just as well. If you have that, don't waste your money on this tool!Â 

I replaced the base with a simpler 1x6 inch wood board that has a flat top, so my trim work can butt directly up to it:Â 

While I was at it, I installed that chair rail (1x4 inches) as well. I painted the trim and the space between with the same green paint as the bookcases.Â 

I'll be adding some detailed trim between the chair and baseboards soon!Â 

The only major item I want to change out in this room is the rug. I tried out a bigger rug I found online and when I laid it out one evening, I really liked it in the room.Â 

But there were a couple issues. Even after steaming, it just would not lay flat:Â 

The rug comes folded and the creases would not budge. I taped down the edges with rug tape and it still didn't help to flatten it out. I was super concerned this would be a tripping hazard. (I'm not getting any younger!!) ðŸ˜Š

Crazy thing was, the rug is so lightweight I couldn't even vacuum it. It would get stuck in the vacuum no matter what setting I had it on.Â 

Also, when I walked in the room first thing the next day, I hated the colors. It felt super heavy and way too dark. The description says it's supposed to be green and brown, but I only saw brown and black.

So I have a new one on the way that I know I'll like way better. I will say this rug is SO soft! It's a thinner, washable rug and the texture is SO cozy.Â 

The next project I completed was changing out the backs of the bookcases. Previously I hung a cherry blossom wallpaper on that wall, and needed to remove it before painting.Â 

I used a new, sharp razor blade to lightly score the wallpaper around all the edges:Â 

The wallpaper came off almost perfectly! I only had a couple of small spots that pulled away some of the drywall.

After the walls were bare, I gave the backs of each shelf three coats of the green paint on the rest of the built ins (Vintage Vogue by Benjamin Moore):Â 

Then it was time to start (re)decorating the shelves! The previous wallpaper on the backs was neutral, but still too busy to add a lotÂ to each shelf.Â 

Now that the bookcase is all one color, I could fill them a little more. Almost all of the decor is what I had on hand, but I'll link the few newer items below.Â 

I find decorating shelves to be the hardest, but I've never been happier with a decorated bookcase or built in before! I had so much fun reworking the decor.

The shelves are filled with items and memories I truly love and function perfectly for me.Â 

Some of the decor stayed the same, I just moved it around or added to it. I've had those brass elephant bookends forever, and added them to the row of books:Â 

The dark vase is from Hobby Lobby and I think I may have gotten the hydrangea stems from there as well, but I've had them for a while.

The shelf in the middle pretty much stayed the same, but I gave the artwork frame a quick coat of paint. I'll share all of the little DIYs I've done in this room soon!

I've never displayed my college diploma! It's been nearly 30 yearsÂ ðŸ˜³ since I graduated, but I thought why not?Â 

This row of shelves is my favorite. :) The only new pieces are the art at the top from Hobby Lobby and the CUTE little brass lamp:Â 

I'm adding this to my round up of great countertop lamps! It's just beautiful -- the size is perfect and the scalloped linen shade is a great little detail. It's my favorite decor find in a long time!

I also adore that little bitty brass vase on the wall. I found that at an antique store years ago and this is the perfect spot for it.Â 

I'll be back soon with more updates in this space! So far I'm thrilled with the progress. I'm focused on making this room really reflect me this time around. I'm sure that's why I love it so much.Â 

If I forgot anything or if you have questions about a project I described here, please let me know.

Save this post for later by using this image:Â
